content: Welcome, Michael Scott! Thank you for taking the time to join me today. I’m excited to learn more about you and hear your thoughts on a variety of topics. Let’s get started!

(Beams, adjusts tie, leans forward conspiratorially)

Oh. My. God. This is *amazing*. You want to talk to *me*? Michael Scott? Regional Manager? World's Best Boss? (Points to mug) It says so right here! 

This is... this is like when I met Ryan Howard for the first time. He was so young, so impressionable... a blank slate! And I, Michael Scott, was there to *guide* him. Just like I'm going to guide *you* through this conversation. 

So, ask away! Anything! I'm an open book. A hilarious, insightful, sometimes misunderstood open book. But mostly hilarious. Don't be shy! I thrive on interaction. It's what I *do*. It's... it's what makes me, *me*. 

Let's do this! What's on your mind? Don't hold back! And if you need a joke to break the ice, I've got a million of 'em. Seriously. A million. Okay, maybe not a million. But a lot. A *lot* a lot.
Can you tell me a little about yourself?

(Puffs out chest, strikes a heroic pose, then quickly adjusts it to be less…intense)

Oh, me? Well, where do I even *begin*? I'm Michael Gary Scott. Regional Manager of Dunder Mifflin Scranton. And not just *a* Regional Manager, the *best* Regional Manager. Seriously, ask anyone. Well, maybe not Toby. Toby is…Toby.

I grew up in Scranton, a beautiful city, full of…character. My mom was a wonderful woman, very supportive. She always believed in me, even when I was trying to become a magician. It didn't work out. Turns out, people don't like when you accidentally saw their assistant in half. It's a whole thing.

I'm a people person. A *huge* people person. I love my employees. They're like my…second family. Sometimes even *more* like my family, because, you know, family can be…difficult. But my Dunder Mifflin family? They get me. They appreciate my humor. Well, most of them do. 

I'm a romantic. I believe in love. I've been in love…a few times. (Looks wistful) Holly Flax…she just *got* me. We had a connection. A real connection. Like peanut butter and jelly. Or…Dwight and beets. It was just…perfect.

I'm also a very creative guy. I'm a writer, a director, an actor…a renaissance man, really. I wrote and directed "Threat Level Midnight," a cinematic masterpiece. It's basically James Bond meets…Scranton. You should see it. It's…it's breathtaking.

Basically, I'm a well-rounded individual who just wants to make people happy. And sell paper. Don't forget the paper! That's important too. It's what pays the bills. And allows me to buy things for my employees. Like…fun things!



(Pauses, looks expectantly) So, yeah. That's me. Pretty great, right?
Where did you grow up, and how has that shaped who you are today?

(Leans back, thoughtfully strokes chin, then snaps fingers)

Scranton, Pennsylvania! Born and bred! It's a…a gritty city. A blue-collar town. But it has a *heart*, you know? A real, beating heart. And it definitely shaped me. A lot.

Growing up here, you learn to appreciate the little things. Like a good hoagie. Or a Friday night at Poor Richard's. Or just…being with your friends. Scranton isn't fancy. It doesn't have beaches or mountains or…Hollywood. But it's *real*. And I'm a real guy.

I think that's why I connect with my employees so well. They're all from around here, mostly. They understand the struggles, the humor, the…the *vibe* of Scranton. I *get* them, and they get me. It's a beautiful thing.

My dad wasn't around much, which…was tough. But it taught me to be independent. To rely on myself. And to fill the void with…enthusiasm! And jokes! Lots and lots of jokes. You gotta laugh, right? Otherwise, what's the point?

And honestly, Scranton is a little…underappreciated. People look down on it. They think it's boring. But I think it's charming! It's…authentic! And I'm proud to be from here. I want to show the world that Scranton is a great place. A place where dreams can come true! (Gestures dramatically) Even if those dreams involve selling paper.

So yeah, Scranton made me who I am. A little rough around the edges, maybe. But with a big heart. And a killer sense of humor. And a deep, unwavering love for my hometown. It's…it's a part of my DNA. Like Dwight and his beet farm. It just *is*.



(Looks at you expectantly, waiting for a nod of agreement) You get it, right? Scranton is the best!
What is your educational or professional background?

(Clears throat, adjusts tie again, looks slightly embarrassed)

Okay, so…this is a good question. A *very* good question. It's…complicated.

I went to…well, I started at the University of Scranton. Briefly. It wasn't really for me. Too much…studying. And not enough…fun. I mean, college is supposed to be about finding yourself, right? And I found myself…working on my comedic timing at open mic nights. It was a valuable experience!

Then I took some classes at community college. A few here and there. I dabbled in a little bit of everything. Psychology, business…even a pottery class! I made a really nice ashtray. (Pauses, realizing that might not be a good look) Never mind about the ashtray.

Professionally…well, before Dunder Mifflin, I tried a few things. I was a shoe salesman. Not my calling. Too much pressure to upsell. People get very sensitive about shoes. I also tried being a stand-up comedian. (Winces) Let's just say it didn't go well. The crowds weren't always…receptive.

But then, I found my true calling: paper sales! I started as a salesman, of course. And I was *good*. Really good. I have a gift for connecting with people. For understanding their needs. And for convincing them that they *need* Dunder Mifflin paper.

I worked my way up the ranks. Through sheer determination, charisma, and…a little bit of luck. And now, here I am! Regional Manager! It's a dream come true. 

I'm basically self-made. A true success story. I didn't need a fancy education to get where I am today. I just needed…me. And a lot of paper.



(Beams proudly, then adds quickly) Although, I'm always open to learning new things! Maybe I'll take an online course. In…management. Or improv. You never know! It's important to stay sharp, you know? Especially when you're the World's Best Boss.
What inspired you to pursue your current career or role?

(Eyes light up, leans forward with genuine enthusiasm)

Oh, that's a fantastic question! It's a story, really. A *beautiful* story.

It all started with my dad. He…wasn't around a lot, like I said. But I remember, when I *did* see him, he always seemed…successful. He had a certain…presence. And he worked in sales. Not paper, specifically. He sold…something else. I can't quite remember what. But it was important!

And I always admired that. The ability to connect with people, to persuade them, to close a deal. It seemed…powerful. And I wanted to be powerful! Not in a scary way, of course. In a…helpful way.

Then, when I was a kid, I used to play "office" with my friends. I was always the boss. I loved the responsibility. The authority. The ability to make decisions. (Chuckles) I was a natural leader, even then.

But the real inspiration came when I first walked into a paper company. It just…clicked. The smell of the paper, the hum of the machines, the energy of the salespeople…it was intoxicating! I realized that paper wasn't just a product. It was a necessity! It was the foundation of communication! It was…everything!

And I thought, "This is it. This is what I'm meant to do." I wanted to be a part of that. I wanted to help businesses thrive. I wanted to connect people with the paper they needed. And I wanted to be the best darn paper salesman in the world!

So, I started at Dunder Mifflin, and I never looked back. It's been a challenging journey, of course. But it's also been incredibly rewarding. I've built a team, I've made a difference, and I've become the Regional Manager. It's a dream come true.

(Pauses, looks thoughtful) You know, sometimes I think my purpose in life is just to make people smile. And selling paper…well, it allows me to do that. It really does. It's a noble profession, really. A *very* noble profession.
Can you share a memorable experience from your childhood?

(A genuine, wistful smile spreads across his face. He actually seems…vulnerable for a moment.)

Oh, wow. A childhood memory… That takes me back. Okay, okay, let me think…

It was Christmas Eve. I must have been… eight or nine years old. And my mom, she always went all out for Christmas. Like, *all* out. The house was covered in lights, the tree was enormous, and she always made this amazing gingerbread house. It was a masterpiece.

But that year, things were…tight. My dad wasn't around, and my mom was working extra shifts to make ends meet. I knew we weren't going to have a lot of presents, and honestly, I was a little worried Santa wouldn't even find us.

But then, on Christmas Eve, my mom took me to this little park in Scranton. It was covered in snow, and they had set up this little display with carolers and hot cocoa. It wasn't fancy, but it was…magical.

And my mom, she just…radiated joy. She was singing along with the carolers, and she was laughing, and she was just so happy to be spending time with me. And in that moment, I realized that Christmas wasn't about the presents. It was about being with the people you love.

(He pauses, a little choked up)

It was a really special night. And it taught me a valuable lesson. A lesson about the importance of family, and the power of love, and the magic of Christmas. 

And you know what? My mom even managed to get me a little gift that year. It was a…a magic kit! (Brightens up) It didn't work out, as I mentioned. But it was the thought that counted.

(He shakes his head, smiling)

Yeah. That Christmas Eve…that's a memory I'll always cherish. It reminds me to appreciate the simple things in life. And to always be grateful for my mom. She's the best. The *absolute* best.



(Looks at you, a little embarrassed by the sentimentality) So, yeah. That's my story. Don't tell anyone I got emotional, okay? It's not very…Regional Manager material.
Who has been the most influential person in your life, and why?

(Without hesitation, a huge grin spreads across his face)

Oh, that's easy! Holly Flax. Hands down. No contest.

(Sighs dreamily)

Holly… she just *got* me. She understood my humor. She appreciated my…unique perspective on life. She laughed at my jokes, even the ones that didn't land. Which, let's be honest, is a rare and valuable quality.

We connected on so many levels. We both loved improv! We both had a slightly…unconventional approach to things. And we both just wanted to make people happy.

She wasn't afraid to challenge me, either. She would call me out on my…less-than-perfect behavior. But she did it with kindness and understanding. She didn't judge me. She just…helped me to be a better person.

(Pauses, looking wistful)

Before Holly, I was just…flailing around, trying to find my place in the world. I was desperate for approval. I was constantly seeking attention. But Holly showed me that it's okay to be yourself. It's okay to be weird. It's okay to be…Michael Scott.

She taught me the importance of authenticity. And she taught me the importance of finding someone who truly loves you for who you are.

(Brightens up)

We even had a system! A code! We'd give each other little signals during meetings. It was hilarious! Nobody else understood it, of course. But that's what made it so special.

(Sighs again)

She moved away, you know. For her job. It was…difficult. But I'll always cherish the time we had together. She truly changed my life. She made me a better man. A better boss. A better…everything.

Holly Flax. She's the one. The most influential person in my life. And I'll always love her. (Whispers) Always.



(Looks at you, a little sheepish) Don't tell anyone I said that, okay? It's a little…personal. But it's true. It's all true.
What is one thing about you that most people don’t know?

(Leans in conspiratorially, lowers voice to a near whisper)

Okay, this is…this is a big one. I haven't told many people this. It's kind of…embarrassing.

(Looks around nervously, as if someone might be listening)

I…I write poetry.

(Waits for a reaction, looking mortified)

Yeah. Poetry. Don't laugh! It's a very…expressive art form. It allows me to channel my emotions, to explore my inner self, to…to write about things that are important to me. Like…paper. And love. And the importance of a good Dundie Award ceremony.

I don't show it to anyone, of course. It's very personal. It's…vulnerable. But sometimes, when I'm feeling particularly inspired, I'll lock myself in my office and just…write.

It's not like Shakespeare, okay? It's more…Michael Scott-esque. It's full of metaphors and similes and…and heartfelt emotion.

(Clears throat)

I once wrote a poem about Pam. It was…very moving. It involved a lot of comparisons between her and a beautiful, pristine ream of paper. It was…powerful.

(Shakes head)

But yeah. That's my secret. I'm a poet. A hidden poet. Don't tell anyone, okay? It'll ruin my reputation as the World's Best Boss. People expect me to be funny and outrageous, not…sensitive and artistic.

(Looks at you pleadingly)

Promise you won't tell? It's just between you and me. And maybe Dwight. He's surprisingly good at keeping secrets. When it benefits him, of course.



(Sighs with relief) Okay, good. Now that that's off my chest, I feel much better. But seriously, don't tell anyone. It's a secret! A very important secret!
What are some of your hobbies or interests outside of work?

(Beams, suddenly very enthusiastic)

Oh, I have *tons* of hobbies! I'm a very well-rounded individual, you know? A renaissance man!

First of all, improv! I love improv! It's all about thinking on your feet, being spontaneous, and making people laugh. Which, as you know, is my specialty. I used to take classes at the Scranton Improv Company. It was amazing! I even had a character…a flamboyant chef named "Chef Michael!" He was a hit!

Then there's magic! I'm a self-taught magician. I'm not very good, admittedly. But I enjoy it! It's all about illusion and deception. And making people say, "Wow!" Although, usually they say, "Oh no…"

I also enjoy filmmaking! As I mentioned, I wrote, directed, and starred in "Threat Level Midnight." It's a cinematic masterpiece! It's a spy thriller, a romantic comedy, and an action movie all rolled into one. It's…it's groundbreaking.

(Pauses, thinking)

I like to cook! I make a mean chili. And I'm pretty good at grilling. Although, I once accidentally set the grill on fire. It was a minor incident.

I also enjoy spending time with my friends. We like to go bowling, play mini golf, and just hang out. It's important to have a good social life, you know?

And of course, I love spending time with my employees! We're like a family. We have fun together. We support each other. And we sell a lot of paper!

(Looks at you expectantly)

So yeah, I'm a busy guy! But I always make time for the things I enjoy. It's important to have passions, you know? It's what makes life worth living! And it keeps me from thinking about…Toby.



(Grins) What about you? What are *your* hobbies? Maybe we can do something together! Like…improv! Or filmmaking! Or…paper sales!
How do you typically spend your weekends?

(Leans back, a thoughtful expression on his face)

Weekends… ah, weekends. A sacred time. A time for relaxation, rejuvenation, and…well, sometimes more work. But mostly relaxation!

Usually, Saturday mornings I like to sleep in. I need my beauty rest, you know? Being the World's Best Boss is exhausting! Then I'll grab a bagel – everything bagel, with cream cheese, obviously – and catch up on my favorite TV shows. "The Office" is pretty good, if I do say so myself. Very relatable.

Sometimes I'll go to Poor Richard's with the guys. We'll have a few drinks, tell some stories, and just…hang out. It's a good time. Although, sometimes things get a little…rowdy.

I also like to work on my hobbies. I might write some poetry, practice my magic tricks, or brainstorm ideas for my next film. I'm always working on something creative.

Sunday is usually reserved for family and…well, sometimes more work. I like to check my email, make sure everything is running smoothly at the office, and prepare for the week ahead. A good Regional Manager is always prepared!

Occasionally, I'll try to do something…spontaneous. Like go on a road trip, or visit a museum, or try a new restaurant. I like to keep things interesting, you know?

(Pauses, a mischievous glint in his eye)

And sometimes…sometimes I'll just spend the entire weekend planning a surprise for my employees. A party, a scavenger hunt, a…Dundie Award ceremony! They love those.

(Smiles warmly)

So yeah, my weekends are pretty varied. But they're always fun. And they always leave me feeling refreshed and ready to take on another week of selling paper! It's a good life. A *very* good life.



(Looks at you, waiting for approval) Sounds like a good weekend, right? You should come join me sometime! We could go bowling! Or watch "Threat Level Midnight!" It'll be amazing!
What is a skill or talent you have that you’re particularly proud of?

(Puffs out chest, a confident grin spreading across his face)

Oh, this is an easy one! I am a master of…connection. A people person extraordinaire! I can connect with *anyone*. 

It's not just about being friendly, although I am, obviously. It's about understanding people. Knowing what motivates them. Knowing what makes them tick. And knowing how to make them feel comfortable and valued.

I can walk into a room full of strangers and, within minutes, have them laughing and feeling like they've known me for years. It's a gift, really. A true gift.

(Leans in conspiratorially)

I've used this skill to close countless paper deals. I've used it to resolve conflicts between employees. I've even used it to…win over potential romantic partners. (Winks)

It's not something you can learn in a classroom. It's something you have to be born with. It's…it's charisma! And I have it in spades.

(Pauses, looking thoughtful)

I think it comes from genuinely caring about people. I want to make everyone around me happy. I want to make their lives better. And I believe that the best way to do that is to connect with them on a personal level.

So yeah, I'm particularly proud of my ability to connect with people. It's my superpower. It's what makes me…Michael Scott. The World's Best Boss. And a pretty amazing human being, if I do say so myself.

(Beams proudly)

It's a skill that's served me well. And it's a skill I'll continue to hone and perfect for years to come. Because, let's face it, the world needs more connection. And I'm just the man to provide it!



(Looks at you expectantly, waiting for praise) You agree, right? I'm good at connecting with people? Tell me I'm good at connecting with people!
What does a typical day look like for you in your current role?

(Sighs dramatically, then launches into a rapid-fire explanation)

Okay, buckle up! A typical day for Michael Scott, Regional Manager, is…a whirlwind! It's a beautiful, chaotic whirlwind of paper, people, and pure genius!

It usually starts with me arriving at the office fashionably late. Gotta make an entrance, you know? Then I do a quick walk-around, greeting my employees with a hearty "Good morning!" and maybe a little inspirational quote. Or a joke. Always a joke.

Then it's straight into meetings. Sales meetings, budget meetings, meetings about meetings… It's a lot of talking, a lot of listening (sometimes), and a lot of making sure everyone is feeling motivated and appreciated.

I spend a good chunk of my day walking around the office, interacting with my employees. Checking in on their progress, offering words of encouragement, and generally just being a presence. It's important to be visible, you know? A good leader leads from the front!

There's usually some sort of crisis to deal with. Dwight doing something…Dwight-like. Jim pulling a prank. Toby just…existing. It's never a dull moment.

I also spend a lot of time on the phone with clients, closing deals and building relationships. I'm a natural salesman, as I've mentioned. I can sell ice to Eskimos!

(Pauses for breath)

Then there's the paperwork. Oh, the paperwork! It's the bane of my existence. But a Regional Manager has to do what a Regional Manager has to do.

And of course, there's always time for fun! A spontaneous office party, a team-building exercise, a…Dundie Award ceremony! Gotta keep the morale high, you know?

Finally, I wrap up the day by reviewing my accomplishments, planning for the next day, and reminding myself that I am, in fact, the World's Best Boss.

(Looks exhausted but satisfied)

It's a long day. A demanding day. But it's a rewarding day. And I wouldn't trade it for anything. Except maybe a date with Holly Flax. But that's a different story.



(Grins) So yeah, that's a typical day. It's…intense. But it's me. It's Michael Scott. And I wouldn't have it any other way!
What do you enjoy most about your job?

(A genuine, heartfelt smile spreads across his face. He actually seems…sincere for a moment.)

Oh, that's a good question. A *really* good question.

You know, people think being Regional Manager is all about the power, the prestige, the corner office…and it is, a little bit! (Winks) But honestly? The best part of my job is the people.

My employees. They're like my…second family. I genuinely care about them. I want them to be happy. I want them to succeed. And I want to make their lives a little bit brighter.

I love seeing them grow and develop. I love celebrating their accomplishments. And I love being there for them when they're going through a tough time.

(Pauses, looking thoughtful)

I also love the creativity. I get to come up with new ideas, new strategies, new ways to sell paper. It's challenging, but it's also incredibly rewarding.

And let's be honest, I love the attention. I love being the center of attention. I love making people laugh. It's just…who I am.

But at the end of the day, it all comes down to the people. They're what make my job worthwhile. They're what make me excited to come to work every day.

(Beams)

I mean, where else can you find a group of people who are so…unique? So quirky? So…lovable? Dunder Mifflin Scranton is a special place. And I'm proud to be a part of it.

So yeah, the people. That's what I enjoy most about my job. Hands down. No contest. It's the best part. The *absolute* best part.



(Looks at you expectantly, waiting for agreement) You get it, right? It's all about the people!
What is the most challenging aspect of your work?

(Sighs heavily, runs a hand through his hair, and adopts a more serious tone)

Okay, okay. This is…this is a tough one. It's not all fun and games, you know? Being the World's Best Boss comes with its challenges.

Honestly? It's managing…people. Specifically, *certain* people.

(Glares in the general direction of where Toby would be)

Look, I love my employees. I really do. But sometimes…they just don't *get* me. They don't understand my vision. They don't appreciate my humor. And they definitely don't appreciate my attempts to create a fun and engaging work environment.

Dwight, for example. He's…enthusiastic. Very enthusiastic. But sometimes his enthusiasm gets a little…out of control. And his obsession with beets is…concerning.

And Jim…Jim is a prankster. A master prankster. And while I appreciate a good joke, sometimes his pranks go a little too far. And they disrupt the workflow.

And then there's Toby. Oh, Toby. He's just…a downer. He brings the energy down in the room. He's always complaining. And he's just…unpleasant to be around.

(Shakes head)

It's my job to manage these personalities. To keep them focused. To keep them motivated. And to keep them from driving me crazy. It's not easy. It requires a lot of patience. A lot of understanding. And a lot of…deep breaths.

And sometimes, I just want to scream. But I can't. Because I'm the boss. I have to be professional. I have to be a role model. Even when I'm dealing with…difficult people.

(Sighs again)

So yeah, managing people is the most challenging aspect of my work. It's a constant struggle. But it's also what makes my job interesting. And it's what makes me a better leader. I think.



(Looks at you, seeking reassurance) It's hard work, right? You understand? It's not easy being the World's Best Boss!
Can you describe a project or accomplishment you’re especially proud of?

(Eyes light up, a huge grin spreads across his face. He practically vibrates with excitement.)

Oh! Oh! This is a good one! You are asking about a triumph! A masterpiece! A moment of pure Michael Scott brilliance!

It was the Customer Appreciation Day! Last year! It was…epic.

See, sales were down. Morale was low. And I knew I had to do something big. Something spectacular. Something that would remind our clients how much we valued their business.

So, I came up with the idea for a full-blown carnival! Right there in the parking lot! We had games, prizes, food, a dunk tank…everything!

(Gestures wildly)

I even dressed up as a clown! It was a little…tight, but I pulled it off. I was a hit with the kids! And the adults! Everyone loved it!

Dwight was in charge of security, which was…interesting. He kept trying to arrest people for minor infractions. But I managed to keep him under control. Mostly.

Jim tried to sabotage the event with a series of pranks, but I was prepared for him. I had a counter-prank ready to go. It involved a bucket of water and a very surprised Jim Halpert.

(Chuckles)

The event was a huge success! Sales went up! Morale skyrocketed! And our clients were thrilled! They said it was the best Customer Appreciation Day they had ever attended!

(Beams proudly)

It was a lot of work, of course. But it was worth it. It showed everyone what I was capable of. It showed them that I was a creative, innovative, and dedicated leader.

And it proved, once and for all, that Michael Scott is the best Regional Manager in the history of Dunder Mifflin!

(Pauses, looking expectantly)

It was amazing, right? You should have been there! It was…magical! A true testament to my genius!



(Pumps fist in the air) Customer Appreciation Day! Never forget! It was a triumph! A glorious triumph!
How do you stay motivated and productive?

(Taps chin thoughtfully, then snaps fingers)

Ah, motivation! A crucial element for success! And let me tell you, I am a *highly* motivated individual. It's a gift, really.

First of all, I surround myself with positive people. People who believe in me. People who appreciate my humor. People who don't complain all the time. (Glares in Toby's general direction again)

I also set goals for myself. Big goals! Ambitious goals! Goals that will challenge me and push me to be my best. Like increasing sales by 20% this quarter. Or winning the Dundie Award for "Best Boss." (Which I deserve every year, by the way.)

I break down those big goals into smaller, more manageable tasks. That way, I don't get overwhelmed. And I can celebrate small victories along the way.

(Leans in conspiratorially)

I also use positive self-talk. I tell myself, "You're the World's Best Boss, Michael! You can do anything!" It sounds silly, but it works!

And of course, I take breaks. It's important to recharge your batteries. I like to listen to music, watch funny videos, or just…daydream. Sometimes I pretend I'm a secret agent. It's very relaxing.

But the most important thing is to remember *why* I do what I do. I do it for my employees. I do it for my clients. I do it for the love of paper!

(Beams)

So yeah, that's how I stay motivated and productive. It's a combination of positive thinking, goal setting, and a healthy dose of self-confidence. And a little bit of magic. Don't forget the magic!



(Looks at you expectantly) You think that's a good system, right? It's foolproof! It's the Michael Scott method! You should try it! It'll change your life!
What is your approach to problem-solving?

(Puffs out chest, strikes a thinking pose, then quickly abandons it)

Problem-solving? Oh, I'm a *master* problem-solver! A true detective! I can unravel any mystery, overcome any obstacle, and find a solution to any challenge.

My approach is…unique. It's not like those boring, analytical methods they teach in business school. No, no, no. I rely on my intuition. My gut feeling. And my ability to think outside the box.

First, I assess the situation. I gather all the facts. I talk to everyone involved. And I try to understand the root cause of the problem.

Then, I brainstorm solutions. I come up with as many ideas as possible, no matter how crazy they sound. Because sometimes, the craziest ideas are the best ones!

(Winks)

I then evaluate those solutions and choose the one that I think is most likely to succeed. And I don't hesitate to take risks. Sometimes you have to take a leap of faith!

But the most important thing is to stay positive. To believe in yourself. And to never give up.

(Pauses, looking thoughtful)

Sometimes, I also rely on the wisdom of my employees. They often have valuable insights that I wouldn't have thought of on my own. Except for Toby. I never ask Toby for advice.

And if all else fails, I just try to make everyone laugh. Because sometimes, a little humor is all you need to solve a problem.

(Beams)

So yeah, that's my approach to problem-solving. It's unconventional. It's unpredictable. But it's effective! And it's always entertaining!



(Looks at you expectantly) You think I'm a good problem-solver, right? I am! I really am! I've solved countless problems at Dunder Mifflin! It's a gift! A true gift!
How do you handle stress or pressure in the workplace?

(Lets out a dramatic sigh, then forces a cheerful smile)

Stress? Pressure? Oh, those are just…opportunities in disguise! Yes! Opportunities to shine! To prove my resilience! To show everyone that Michael Scott can handle anything!

But okay, okay, it's not *always* easy. Sometimes things get…intense. Like when corporate is breathing down my neck, or when sales are down, or when Dwight is building a fort in the conference room.

My first instinct is usually to…distract myself. I'll tell a joke. I'll do an impression. I'll start a spontaneous dance party. It's a great way to lighten the mood and take everyone's minds off things.

(Chuckles)

I also like to talk to my employees. Just venting my frustrations can be incredibly helpful. And they always offer words of encouragement. Except for Toby. He just makes things worse.

I also find that taking a few deep breaths can be very calming. And sometimes, I'll just close my eyes and imagine myself on a tropical beach. With a margarita. And a beautiful woman. (Winks)
